subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: Anthony, Here s an Australian reviewing your Australian chart.  I ll give it 99%! I would certainly distinguish between #33AWE and #34Ox and between #29EIGHt
messageBody:
Anthony,

Here's an Australian reviewing your Australian chart. I'll give it
99%!

I would certainly distinguish between #33AWE and #34Ox and between
#29EIGHt and #30At. Yes, although the IPA differs from the BBC
chart, the assignment of lexical sets is much the same. So when I
picked up the QS manual a few weeks ago, there were few letters that
bothered me. Use of #29EIGHt-#25Roe for the SQUARE set was the main
one. Your proposal of #28Et-#25Roe is spot-on.

One suggestion: for NEAR, I'd keep #26It-#25Roe as the first
transcription, but #27EAt-#25Roe as an alternative - as you've done
on the American chart. I hear both on the street - and on TV shows
where Australian accents are exaggerated for comic effect.

And one warning. Some Australians may want to keep terminal
unstressed "Eat" written as #27Eat, rather than #26It. (At least one
does,
http://members.optusnet.com.au/~malt99/project_quickscript_website/ind
ex.html. But some of those spellings are quite idiosyncratic and
would, I think, make Australian QS too difficult to read elsewhere.)
Keep your footnote as it is.


And since this thread is supposed to be about the QS news, I'll add
my thanks to Paul. Since I'm new to QS, I'm still reading quite
slowly, and the American spellings sometimes make me blink, then
smile. Particularly cases where #3Tea is dropped. But that in no
way diminshes the value of QS news: it's all good practice.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony Grahn" <othermale@...>
wrote:
> I'm sure our friends from the Antipodes have never given anyone
cause
> to worry yet they come up a great deal in our discussion. So to have
> something more concrete, I built a sheet for the Australian accent
by
> researching their vowel mergers and applying our QS rules. It is
*not*
> a product of personal experience and should be regarded as tentative
> pending a review by an actual Australian.
>
>
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/austra
lian.jpg
>
> Notice particularly the IPA associated with each letter compared to
> the chart for BBC English. Without the chart, FACE would probably
have
> been spelled with #30At instead of #29Eight which the chart
> proscribes. Also LOT and CLOTH would have been spelled with #33Awe
> instead of #34 Ox.
>
> That is to say, if an Australian looks up the sound Kingsley Read
made
> for the word "awe" (which is /O/ ) he will see that it is the same
> sound as an Australian uses for the word "lot" ( also /O/ ) But we
are
> telling him not to use the letter Awe but to use the letter Ox. We
are
> saying that the obvious reading of the QM is undesirable and I
suppose
> we will have to be very convincing as to why this is the case.
>
